answers.answer: Hello,I can understand your concern about developing diabetes because it's in your family now.  While I'm not a physician, it seems to me that you have good reason to relax a bit, while you stay alert to possible symptoms.Here's what I mean.  I used a website to compute your BMI (Body Mass Index) that's commonly used to assess whether one is underweight, normal, or overweight.  Based on your height, you are of normal weight.  The site I used is this one:http://www.cdc.gov/nccdphp/dnpa/bmi/calc-bmi.htm#MetricBe sure to convert your height into meters (1.77)On to your blood sugar numbers.  Depending on the time of day you have done your random testing, a completely normal non-diabetic may well see numbers above 100.I like to use a resource from the American Diabetes Association (ADA), which is primarily focused on education and has lots of info about pre-diabetes and Type 2 diabetes.  I believe they have affiliates worldwide, so there may be offices near you, too.According to their website, a FASTING (first thing in the morning - no food/beverage after midnight; testing 6-8 hours later), <100 is a normal reading; 100-126 can indicate pre-diabetes; and >126 indicates diabetes.  The website I used is:http://www.diabetes.org/pre-diabetes/pre-diabetes-symptoms.jspOn the ADA website, you'll have access to much information about symptoms, how to prevent pre-diabetes and diabetes, and general advice that seems good for everyone even without diabetes.Finally, you mentioned that you don't exercise regularly.  I can relate to that and am in the same boat.  I do KNOW both from my reading and my personal experience, that during periods when I am exercising rather regularly it is better for my overall health:  blood pressure, diabetes, complexion, oral health, and even my disposition.  Somehow, I allow myself to go thru months where I simply don't exercise.  Your msg (and my writing to you) is another gentle reminder to get back into a good routine!I hope this helps you -- do check back to read others' responses and to share your progress.

Thanks for your reply.  The sites you pointed out gave me a lot of information. A few points I can mention here afer reading your reply are below:1. My father has diabetes since he is 45 years. He is 73 and I am 33 now.2. My mother has recently developed diabetes. She is 65.It has been told that diabetes comes hereditary. I wish to know if there is any way to prevent the diabetes coming as heredetary.3. My blood pressure and heart rate is normal.  Mostly I get  80 and 120  and pulse near to 70.4. My work changes every fornight from day and night *****.  I think this also changes my body metabolism.

Sanalseema,Thnk you for writing to the JDRF Medhelp Forum.  I am a volunteer and not a physician and therfore am not qualified to diagnose Diabetes.   I do know that Diabetes is a complicated disease and ther are different types of diabetes.  Eating sugar does not cause Diabetes in and of itself.  Your body may have a diminished capacity to produce insulin or to use it effectively which may be the cause of your slightly elevated blood sugars.  This may be something that can be helped by reducing your weight or your sugar intake, or by taking medication.  A physician would really need to evalute your individual situation.  I would encourage you to see an endocrinolist or a physician knowledgeable about Type I and Type II diabetes for some medical guidance.  Good luck.ES
One more point, I have done all my diabetes test in the early morning after 8 hours of fasting.

question: I have done my first diabetes test with my father's monitor (Glucomen PC) and found that its 123. It was six months ago. I was not controlling sweets and other foods that contain glucose/sugar.  I had tested in a clinic the next day and found that the result was 117.  One month later i bought OneTouch Ultra Glucose meter.  Though I have controlled a lot on my sugar intake, the sugar level always comes in between 100 and 120. Does eating sugar added food cause diabetes ?  Why was not my sugar level not coming below 100 even after my food was controlled.  I do not take regualar exercise.  I have 177cm tall and weighs about 76 Kg.  Am I overweight to develop diabetes ?Could you pls let me know how can I reduce my glucose levels below 100 or to a safer level ?A detailed answer is appreciated.
title: Developing Diabetes
